news.title: Judge temporarily blocks Trump administration from freezing child care funding in Illinois, 4 other states
news.text:
A federal judge has temporarily blocked the Trump administration from freezing $10 billion in federal funding for child care assistance, low income and social service funds in Illinois and four other Democrat-led states.

In a brief order issued Friday, Judge Arun Subramanian of New York directed the Trump administration to release funding for the three social services programs for the next two weeks while the lawsuit plays out. The lawsuit was filed Thursday by Illinois and the four other states.

The Trump administration announced earlier this week that Illinois, Minnesota, New York, California and Colorado would be cut off from $7 billion in funding for the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families program, which provides cash assistance for households with children, nearly $2.4 billion for the Child Care and Development Fund, which helps support working parents with child care and around $870 million for social services grants that help children at risk.

It came a week after the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services said it was freezing child care funds in Minnesota and asking for an audit of day care centers amid allegations of fraud by day care centers run by Somali residents.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm pleased with the court‚Äôs decision, which protects critical funding to support families and help working parents access child care,‚Äù Illinois Attorney General Kwame Raoul said in a statement. ‚ÄúThere is no justification for this attempted funding freeze. It is a cruel and illegal attempt by the Trump administration to play politics with the lives of children and low-income families. I remain committed to protecting Illinois residents from bearing the brunt of this president‚Äôs continued disregard for our Constitution and the rule of law.‚Äù

A spokesperson for HHS didn‚Äôt immediately respond to a request for comment.

Illinois was set to cut off from $1 billion in funding across the three programs, according to the state‚Äôs Department of Human Services, which administers the funds. That would have amounted to around 150,000 children being impacted by the funding freeze.

A spokesperson for IDHS said the agency does not anticipate an immediate impact to funding as a result of the judge‚Äôs order.

When announcing the freeze, HHS Assistant Secretary Alex Adams said the federal government is concerned by potential ‚Äúsystemic fraud in Illinois Child Care and Development Fund services.‚Äù He claimed the Trump administration ‚Äúhas reason to believe‚Äù the state is ‚Äúillicitly providing‚Äù CCDF benefits to people without legal status in the U.S.

In their lawsuit, Raoul and the other attorneys general called the fraud allegations, ‚Äúpretextual, vague, and unsubstantiated.‚Äù

At a news conference earlier Friday, before the judge‚Äôs ruling, U.S. Sen. Dick Durbin blasted the Trump administration‚Äôs decision to freeze the funds, warning that children in the targeted states will ‚Äúpay the price.‚Äù

Durbin claimed that the funds, which helps families afford child care, were slashed because Trump received fewer votes in Illinois than former Vice President Kamala Harris in the 2024 election.

‚ÄúWe should not penalize these children for political reasons,‚Äù said Durbin at Concordia Place in Avondale, a child care provider that relies on federal funds to operate. Representatives for the Illinois Action for Children joined Durbin at the event.
news.author: Elleiana Green,Kade Heather

news.title: Judge blocks Trump from freezing $10 billion in child, family aid to five US states
news.text: NEW YORK, Jan 9 (Reuters) - A U.S. judge on Friday temporarily blocked President Donald Trump's administration from freezing access by five Democratic-led states to more than $10 billion of federal funds for childcare and family assistance based on what it said were concerns about fraud. U.S. District Judge Arun Subramanian in Manhattan, an appointee of Democratic former President Joe Biden, said he issued a temporary restraining order for the reasons stated in a legal filing by California, Colorado, Illinois, Minnesota and New York, which filed the lawsuit. The White House did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment on the ruling. The states sued the Trump administration late on Thursday, two days after the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services announced the freeze. Funds that were frozen include more than $7 billion from the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families program, which provides cash to low-income families with children. The funds also included $2.4 billion from the Child Care and Development Fund, which helps make childcare more affordable, and about $870 million in social services grants for children. HHS said it had concerns about "widespread fraud and misuse of taxpayer dollars" in the five states' welfare programs, including the possibility people other than U.S. citizens and lawful permanent residents might be receiving benefits. U.S. Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins on Friday said the Department of Agriculture had frozen federal benefit programs for Minnesota, citing fraud allegations. Minnesota Governor Tim Walz, a Democrat who was former Vice President Kamala Harris' running mate in the 2024 presidential election won by Trump, a Republican, announced on Monday he will not seek a third term so he can focus on the fraud scandal. The five states said HHS lacked a legitimate justification for this week's funding freeze and had usurped Congress' power to allocate the money. They also called the unsubstantiated fraud allegations a pretext to justify the lawsuit, whose real purpose was to "punish perceived political enemies of the Trump Administration by unlawfully withholding critical funding pending purported fraud detection measures unauthorized by any statute." (Reporting by Jack Queen in New York; Editing by Chris Reese) By Jonathan Stempel and Blake Brittain

news.title: 'Fuming' Trump hurled profanity in call to GOP senator: report
news.text:
President Donald Trump reportedly tore into a member of his own party after she voted against his administration earlier this week, according to a new report.

The Hill reported Friday that Trump was apparently "fuming" upon hearing that Sen. Susan Collins (R-Maine) and four other Republicans were planning to vote with Democrats on a procedural motion to advance a war powers resolution this week. The five Republicans gave Democrats a narrow majority on legislation that, if passed, would block Trump from waging war in Venezuela.

Two of the Hill's sources anonymously confided to the publication that the president called Collins while the vote was underway. One source said Trump told Collins that her vote was inhibiting his ability to carry out his duties as commander-in-chief.

"He called her and then basically read her the riot act," an unnamed Senate Republican told the Hill, describing the call as a "profanity-laced rant."

"He was very mad about the vote,‚Äù the source added. "Very mad. Very hot."

Trump's call to Collins is particularly noteworthy given Collins' position as a Republican senator from a predominantly blue state. The Maine Republican is running for another six-year term this fall, and her race is projected to be close, with Democrats Janet Mills ‚Äì the current governor of Maine ‚Äî and U.S. Marine Corps veteran Graham Platner vying to unseat her in the state that voted for Democrat Kamala Harris in 2024 by seven points.

Former Maine Republican state lawmaker Mary Small told Politico on Friday that Trump's consistent attacks on Collins could jeopardize her ability to get reelected and potentially risk the GOP's small majority. Small said Collins' approval rating would likely be much higher among Maine voters if Trump wasn't so vocal in his criticism of her.

Click here to read the Hill's full report.

news.title: 'The Art of the Deal': Oil Giants, Pres. Trump Talk WH Meet-up on Venezuela, 'Long-Term' Effect on Prices
news.text:
On Friday, President Trump hosted representatives of some of the world's largest oil companies at the White House. The president's only complaint seemed to be that the new ballroom wasn't yet complete, because, as he claimed, they could have filled it.

President Trump announced the meeting on Truth Social.

The president wrote:

The largest Oil Companies in the World are coming to the White House at 2:30 P.M. Everybody wants to be there. It‚Äôs too bad that the Ballroom hasn‚Äôt completed because, if it were, it would be PACKED. We apologize to those Oil Companies that we cannot take today, but Secretary of Energy Chris Wright, and Secretary of the Interior Doug Burgum, will see them over the next week. Everyone is in daily contact. Today‚Äôs meeting will almost exclusively be a discussion on Venezuelan Oil, and our longterm relationship with Venezuela, its Security, and People. A very big factor in this involvement will be the reduction of Oil Prices for the American People. Additionally, and perhaps most importantly of all, will be the stoppage of Drugs and Criminals coming into the United States of America. Thank you for your attention to this matter!

A reduction in oil prices would be good - up to a point, of course; if prices drop too far, it can make production in some areas not economically viable. That is, though, often a problem that fixes itself in time. 

Read More: Pre-Dawn Blitz: Navy, Marines Seize Another Tramp Oil Hauler

It's the response from the US Oil & Gas Association, though, that's really interesting.

It's a long post, but here are a few highlights.

Here is our afternoon take on this WH meeting. There are 2 "Must haves" for producers to go back into Venezuela. 1 - We need know our crews are not going to get kidnapped. 2- We need to know investment and capital expenditures are going to be safe from seizure by a foreign government. The overwhelming show of force from the US military on last Saturday morning ‚Äì well, that solves the first problem. 

Indeed, it does - as long as President Trump is in office. Anything past that depends on who wins the presidential election in 2028; if, in January, 2029, sees, say, a President JD Vance and Vice President Marco Rubio inaugurated (just to name a couple of possibilities) then that assurance will last. If a Democrat should win... Well, if that happened, were I an oil company executive, I'd probably be giving some serious thought to divesting of any assets in Venezuela, and getting my people out.

RE: #2 -- I expect that the Administration will put a very interesting set of financing options on the table for US producers that will link Venezuelan investment not to a company‚Äôs CapEx budgets ‚Äì but to the US government‚Äôs international project financing mechanisms such as the ExIm bank or other entities designed to reduce exposure to US interests and investments overseas. Its‚Äôs one thing to have a foreign government seize a company‚Äôs asset ‚Äì but seizing an asset that is financed and back by the US government? Try it and you gonna get another visit in the middle of the night by representatives of the US military.

The same thing as above applies. Not only the midterms but the 2028 elections. We have to keep control, or all this comes flying apart. We have to win these elections, or all this is for naught. Republicans, strangely, have a bad habit of underperforming on midterms; that has to stop. We have to turn out, we have to win, or all this stops. It sounds tiresome, sometimes, to keep proclaiming every upcoming election as "OMG most important election ever," but we are at a critical juncture. We have to keep this momentum up, and the nation can't afford four years of a President Gavin Newsom - or Kamala Harris. 

Back to the US Oil & Gas Association, they make one great, final point:

This is the Art of the Deal and there‚Äôs no one better than the guy who wrote the book.

That right there, that is a natural-born fact. We just need to make sure that deal stays in place.

Editor‚Äôs Note: The Democrat Party has never been less popular as voters reject its globalist agenda.

news.title: ‚ÄòA wreck‚Äô: Legendary ex-late night host rips CBS News in blistering rant
news.text:
David Letterman unleashed a blistering critique of CBS News on Friday, accusing the network where he spent more than two decades on the air of abandoning its integrity and handing control to what he described as ‚Äúidiots.‚Äù

The searing criticism from the 78-year-old former ‚ÄúLate Show‚Äù host came during an appearance on the Barbara Gaines Show, a YouTube program hosted by his longtime producers, according to a The Daily Beast report. Letterman told the hosts the ‚Äúmentality that drove the integrity of CBS News has been trampled on, p---ed on and eviscerated by these idiots that have taken it over.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm at a point now where it‚Äôs really hurting my feelings,‚Äù Letterman added, before declaring, ‚ÄúCBS News is a wreck. It‚Äôs just gone.‚Äù

Letterman‚Äôs remarks were delivered amid sweeping changes at the network he once called home following the merger of parent company Paramount with Skydance Media, led by billionaire David Ellison, according to The Daily Beast. One of Ellison‚Äôs first major moves was installing Free Press founder Barry Weiss as CBS News‚Äô editor in chief last week.

Among the changes at the network include promoting Tony Dokoupil as anchor of its nightly broadcast, which began this week with ‚ÄúMAGA-friendly language‚Äù to viewers, the outlet added Friday.

Letterman has previously criticized CBS leadership, blasting Paramount‚Äôs decision last year to settle a $60 million lawsuit brought by President Donald Trump over a ‚Äú60 Minutes‚Äù edit involving then-Democratic candidate Kamala Harris. At the time, Letterman called the settlement ‚Äúpure cowardice.‚Äù

news.title: Billie Eilish Shares Posts Calling ICE a ‚ÄòTerrorist Group‚Äô in Light of Minneapolis¬†Shooting
news.text:
Skip to main content

Billie Eilish at the ‚ÄúAvatar: Fire and Ash‚Äù World Premiere held at the Dolby Theatre on Dec. 1, 2025, in Los Angeles.

Michael Buckner/Variety

Billie Eilish is using her platform to amplify protests against the United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement, which has come under fire (even more than usual) for the killing of a Minnesota woman earlier this week.

On Friday (Jan. 9) ‚Äî two days after 37-year-old Renee Nicole Good was fatally shot by an ICE officer during an immigration enforcement operation in Minneapolis ‚Äî the pop star shared several back-to-back posts condemning the organization. The first one was a graphic calling ICE a ‚Äúfederally funded and supported terrorist group,‚Äù with the original creator describing the agency‚Äôs actions as ‚Äútearing apart families, terrorizing citizens, and now murdering innocent people.‚Äù

Billie Eilish Pushes for Gun Control Amid ‚ÄòDevastating‚Äô Shootings in U.S. & Australia: ‚ÄòRaise Your Voice‚Äô

John Mulaney Postpones Minneapolis Shows Following ICE Killing of Renee Nicole Good: ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs Happening in Your City Is Heartbreaking‚Äô

Billie Eilish Condemns Israel Defense Minister‚Äôs Plan to Forcibly Relocate Palestinians: ‚ÄòHorrifying‚Äô

The second post Eilish reshared on her Story calls on the country to ‚Äúabolish ICE,‚Äù listing 32 people who reportedly died in ICE custody last year. The third encourages U.S. citizens to call their representatives in Congress to demand that ICE be defunded, and for the officer who fired the deadly shot in Minneapolis to be arrested and charged immediately.

Billboard has reached out to the White House and the Department of Homeland Security for comment.

ICE‚Äôs actions under the Donald Trump administration have been polarizing since he took office a year ago, but backlash has reached an all-time high this week following the scene in Minneapolis. The DHS, the president and Vice President JD Vance have all claimed that Good was trying to run over the agents with her car leading up to the shooting, and that the officer in question was acting in self defense; however, widely circulated video footage of the incident shows that Good had actually been driving the opposite way.

Even Trump struggled to explain what happened after he personally watched the video of the shooting in the Oval Office with a New York Times reporter also in the room. ‚ÄúWell ‚Ä¶ I ‚Ä¶ the way I look at it ‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs a terrible scene,‚Äù the newspaper reports of the twice-impeached POTUS‚Äô reaction to the footage. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs horrible to watch. No, I hate to see it.‚Äù

Eilish has long been vocal in her opposition to Trump‚Äôs policies, endorsing his opponent, Kamala Harris, in the 2024 election. Prior to Friday, the nine-time Grammy winner had also shared other posts condemning the ICE raids in her home city of Los Angeles.

news.author: Hannah Dailey

news.title: David Letterman Eviscerates ‚ÄòIdiots‚Äô at CBS News
news.text:
David Letterman, 78, tore into the network he called home for 22 years.

The ‚Äúmentality that drove the integrity of CBS News has been trampled on, p---ed on and eviscerated by these idiots that have taken it over,‚Äù Letterman said new video posted Friday.

Letterman joined The Barbara Gaines Show, a YouTube talk show hosted by Letterman‚Äôs longtime producers Barbara Gaines and Mary Barclay, to share his thoughts.

‚ÄúCBS News is a wreck. It‚Äôs just gone,‚Äù Letterman asserted during a conversation with two of his longtime producers.

Letterman was referring to the massive changes that have been underway at CBS News since the network‚Äôs parent company Paramount merged with billionaire scion David Ellison‚Äôs Skydance Media last year. 

Ellison quickly installed The Free Press founder Bari Weiss as CBS News‚Äô new editor-in-chief. Late last month, Weiss made an 11th-hour decision to pull a 60 Minutes story that was critical of President Trump. 

This week, she has begun to remake CBS Evening News by promoting Tony Dokoupil, 45, to anchor that nightly broadcast. Dokoupil began his tenure by inserting MAGA-friendly language into messages to viewers. 

Letterman joined CBS in 1993, earning more than 50 Emmy nominations over 22 years as the network‚Äôs Late Show host before handing the show over to Stephen Colbert in 2015.

Later in the video, he noted that television is ‚Äúrunning out of places‚Äù for talk show hosts who use political satire, such as Jimmy Kimmel, Seth Meyers, and Stephen Colbert.

‚ÄúWhat people don‚Äôt understand is that Jimmy Kimmel single-handedly brought the people at Disney, and all of those other network television owners, to their knees,‚Äù Letterman said. ‚ÄúHe made them appear to be the fools that they are and continues to call attention to the plight.‚Äù

When Colbert, who Letterman described as a ‚Äúprecise, quick, witty political satirist,‚Äù was announced to be leaving CBS, the comedian did not shy away from sharing his objections.

‚ÄúThey did not handle Stephen Colbert, the face of their network, the way they should‚Äôve,‚Äù Letterman declared at the time. 

In July 2025, CBS‚Äôs parent company, Paramount, settled a $16 million lawsuit with President Trump over a misleading edit in its 60 Minutes segment featuring then-presidential candidate Kamala Harris.

Just weeks after the settlement was announced, CBS announced the vocal White House critic‚Äôs premature departure in May 2026. Letterman described the announcement as ‚Äúpure cowardice.‚Äù
news.summary:
Jamie McCarthy / Jamie McCarthy/WireImage for Rock and Roll Hall of FameDavid Letterman, 78, tore into the network he called home for 22 years.

The ‚Äúmentality that drove the integrity of CBS News has been trampled on, p---ed on and eviscerated by these idiots that have taken it over,‚Äù Letterman said new video posted Friday.

Read more at The Daily Beast.
news.author: Owen Mason-Hill

news.title: In reelection launch, Josh Shapiro admits violent attack almost drove him from race
news.text:
The crowd was loud and enthusiastic, packed with local figures such as newly sworn-in Pittsburgh Mayor Cory O‚ÄôConnor and labor leaders, including Darrin Kelly of the Allegheny-Fayette Labor Council, alongside scores of trade and union workers filling the cavernous hall.

Visually, the rollout differed from Shapiro‚Äôs 2022 kickoff along the river in Johnstown. Substantively, however, it was familiar: a message rooted in the importance of place.

In an exclusive interview with the Washington Examiner after the speech, before departing for his Philadelphia announcement, Shapiro summed it up simply: different location, same goal ‚Äî ensuring every community in Pennsylvania gets a fair shot.

‚ÄúI wanted to be focused here in the union hall on those who I believe are going to make up the power of the next generation of workers in Pennsylvania,‚Äù he said of the trade union members who are already working on shovel-ready energy projects in the region.

‚ÄúIf we don‚Äôt invest in skills-based labor, we‚Äôre not going to have as bright a future in our commonwealth,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd so that‚Äôs why I‚Äôm here today, focused on what I think is the ability to help every Pennsylvanian chart their own course and achieve success. And so much of that runs through halls like this one.‚Äù

Before Shapiro took to the stage, one of the people who stepped up ahead of him was a man who goes by ‚ÄúTim O‚Äù, a 52-year-old father who is on his second career and his second year in a carpentry apprenticeship. Tim became choked up when he said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt look like other apprentices.‚Äù

Shapiro said Tim was an example of his administration‚Äôs investment in trade programs in a state where over 60% of the population did not attend college and that it was important to give him a platform.

‚ÄúOne of the things I always ask the apprentices is, ‚ÄòHey, how‚Äôd you get here? What brought you here? What was your journey?‚Äô Some of them come right out of high school, and we want to create those pathways,‚Äù Shapiro explained of the variety of answers he has received over the years. ‚ÄúSome of them go to college for a year, realize it‚Äôs not for them. Some of them have different careers and then find their ways here.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe key is opening up the doors to places like this and showing people it exists because we need people like Tim O., who, even at 52 to dedicate their lives to having the skills we need to produce more energy, to quite literally build bridges and build buildings,‚Äù Shapiro said.

The speech was filled with stories highlighting accomplishments, future goals, and governing with purpose, and included a brief swipe at the bipartisan chaos in Washington. Notably, Shapiro avoided inflammatory language, steering clear of demonizing Republicans or President Donald Trump.

And he uses the word ‚Äúwe‚Äù instead of ‚ÄúI‚Äù when discussing accomplishments, something many politicians cannot find a way to do.

‚ÄúI obviously have profound differences from the president. You have written about that,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúNo one expects us to agree on everything. But to me, vilifying others, attacking others, is not a way to bring people together and get stuff done.‚Äù

Shapiro, who has a good relationship with Sen. Dave McCormick (R-PA), said his job is to champion the things people can do together for the commonwealth.

‚ÄúMy focus is on building bridges, creating more opportunity for folks to come together, and delivering results for people like Tim O. and others who need help,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd so, to me, I want this campaign to be hopeful. I want to highlight differences where we have different policy views, but I want to focus on uplifting people.‚Äù

Larry Ceisler, a Washington County native and Philadelphia-based public affairs official, said the reason you do not see Shapiro go personal on Trump is that, first of all, that is always who he has been and, second, because he always wants his governance to be about purpose, not divisiveness.

‚ÄúHe always tries to make it substantive and not personal because he never wants to be perceived as attacking the people who support the president, so when he does criticize, it is based on the issues,‚Äù Ceisler said.

Shapiro begins his launch with a formidable amount of cash. This week, his campaign announced he ended 2025 with over $30 million in cash on hand and a Quinnipiac University poll that showed Shapiro‚Äôs favorability rating at 58%.

He faces Republican Stacy Garrity, the state treasurer, who has won back-to-back races for that statewide elected office. Garrity said in a statement that ‚ÄúJosh Shapiro is more concerned with a promotion to Pennsylvania Avenue than serving hardworking Pennsylvanians.‚Äù

Shapiro‚Äôs governorship entered the national spotlight early, shaped by crisis decisions beginning in 2023, shortly after he took office, with the train derailment in East Palestine, Ohio, near the Pennsylvania border. The fiery wreck, visible for miles, was followed by a controlled burn that raised concerns across Beaver and Lawrence counties over toxic contamination in the air and water.

That was followed in June 2023 by a tanker truck crash beneath Interstate 95 in Philadelphia, a vital East Coast artery carrying more than 150,000 vehicles a day. The crash killed the driver and caused the overpass to collapse. Despite predictions that the highway could be closed for years, six temporary lanes reopened within two weeks, allowing traffic to move while permanent repairs were made.

Shapiro was also governor in July 2024 when gunman Thomas Crooks attempted to assassinate Trump, killing local fire chief Cory Comperatore and wounding two others. Shapiro was on the scene in Butler the following morning with first responders and investigators. He was in office as well when Luigi Mangione was arrested in Altoona for the alleged killing of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson, and when three police officers were murdered in York County in the deadliest day for Pennsylvania law enforcement in 16 years.

During that period, Shapiro was also on the short list of possible running mates for 2024 Democratic presidential nominee Kamala Harris, before ultimately determining the role was not the right fit.

Last year, an arsonist attempted to kill Shapiro and his family by firebombing the governor‚Äôs residence, setting the home ablaze, and causing extensive damage. Shapiro, his wife, their children, and other family members narrowly escaped the rapidly spreading flames.

Shapiro has said the attack prompted serious conversations with his wife about whether he should seek reelection.

‚ÄúI think a couple of days after that, my primary focus was on being a good dad and a good husband and being a good governor. And I have tried very, very hard to both heal myself and be there for my kids as they work through this and be there for Laurie,‚Äù he said of his wife, who was with him at the beginning of the interview.

Shapiro admits there were many family discussions on what they should do.

‚ÄúWe had a long talk about whether we wanted to keep doing this in the face of that kind of attack and that kind of threat,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe reality is we all ended up in the exact same place. Yes, we not only have to keep governing, but we‚Äôve got to run again and keep doing this because you can‚Äôt let those who want to inflict pain on others bring harm to communities. You can‚Äôt let them win.‚Äù

Shapiro said he expects to continue working through the aftermath for years, noting that members of both parties privately reached out to check on his well-being and offer help, including Trump, who was himself the target of an assassination attempt.

‚ÄúHe called, and I appreciated that,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd we talked about his brush with death in public. No public officials should have to go through this. Our politics shouldn‚Äôt be this way.‚Äù

Shapiro said he hopes the way he runs his campaign and governs will help lower the temperature and allow for a measure of healing.

‚ÄúI said today in my speech, go talk to that person that voted a different way in the last election and have a respectful conversation,‚Äù Shapiro said. ‚ÄúWe need more of that.‚Äù
news.summary: COLLIER TOWNSHIP, Pennsylvania ‚Äî Gov. Josh Shapiro (D-PA) launched his reelection bid in western Pennsylvania on Thursday, highlighting his accomplishments since taking office in 2023 and outlining his goals for a second term. Despite noting that Republicans and independents were present in the packed carpenters union hall, the only boos came when Shapiro mentioned his […]
news.author: Salena Zito

news.title: 'They're trying to break us': Trump's focus on Minnesota boils over with ICE shooting
news.text: Two days before Christmas, with federal agents ramping up immigration arrests in Minnesota, Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey stepped to a microphone and issued a warning. ‚ÄúI am increasingly concerned because of the chaos that is being caused by these ICE agents,‚Äù Frey said. ‚ÄúSomebody is going to get seriously injured or killed.‚Äù Two weeks later, with some 2,000 federal agents ‚Äî more than three times the number of police officers employed by the Minneapolis Police Department ‚Äî deployed to the state, that very thing happened. A federal immigration officer fatally shot Renee Nicole Good, a 37-year-old mother and U.S. citizen, on Wednesday, unleashing a national furor, pitting federal and local officials against each other and drawing thousands of people to the streets in protest. Wednesday‚Äôs deadly confrontation was the culmination of weeks of intensified scrutiny, verbal attacks and even conspiracy theories directed at Minnesota and Gov. Tim Walz by President Donald Trump, his administration and his allies. Exactly why the president has been so fixated on Minnesota isn‚Äôt totally clear, though local officials and strategists working in state and national politics have pointed NBC News to Trump‚Äôs long-running ‚Äî and unsuccessful ‚Äî attempts to win the state and his personal disdain for Walz. Many said it‚Äôs a case of Trump going after deep-blue cities in part due to their immigration policies. A central focus of the administration‚Äôs attacks on Minnesota has also been the Justice Department‚Äôs yearslong fraud investigation that has involved some members of Minnesota‚Äôs Somali community. In 2022, during President Joe Biden‚Äôs administration, federal prosecutors announced initial indictments in what they called a $250 million scheme to defraud a federal child nutrition program. They described Aimee Bock, who is white, as the mastermind of the operation. A jury convicted her in March. So far, prosecutors have charged 92 people and dozens have been convicted. But conservative influencers have latched onto the scandal to push unsubstantiated claims, and Trump has used it to make disparaging remarks about people of Somali descent. For Minnesotans, the result of all this attention has largely been disgust, fury and exhaustion. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre trying to break us,‚Äù said Democratic state Rep. Emma Greenman, whose district is roughly a mile from where the shooting occurred. She said she believes the administration targeted the state because it is ‚Äúa successful story of multiracial democracy and immigration ‚Äî and it inherently represents a threat to authoritarian power.‚Äù White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt told NBC News that Trump ‚Äúloves Minnesota and the people.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a state where he received historic Republican support, and he has long called out Walz for his incompetence and terrible leadership.‚Äù ‚ÄúI wish they would just leave us the f--- alone,‚Äù Democratic Sen. Tina Smith of Minnesota told NBC News on Wednesday. Asked why Trump was so fixated on the state, Smith replied, ‚ÄúI wish I knew.‚Äù 'He's never gotten Walz' Trump has called Walz ‚Äúcorrupt,‚Äù ‚Äúwhacked out‚Äù and ‚Äúgrossly incompetent.‚Äù On Saturday, the president shared a video on social media that promoted a conspiracy theory about a Democratic lawmaker in the state who, along with her husband, was assassinated in June. The video falsely implied that Walz had something to do with the killing. Trump has also repeatedly made derogatory comments in recent weeks about Somali immigrants in Minnesota, calling them ‚Äúscammers‚Äù and ‚Äúlowlifes.‚Äù While the fraud investigation into the use of federal social services funds in Minnesota has received bipartisan support in the past, Somali Americans who run child care facilities, which have been the subject of fresh allegations in the scandal, in the state say they‚Äôve been harassed and threatened since a conservative influencer‚Äôs lengthy video on the issue went viral. Many Democrats in the state have acknowledged that its party leaders have mishandled the situation politically as well. A state audit report released in 2024 found that failures by the state‚Äôs Education Department led to the misuse of the Covid-era program. On Monday, Walz made the surprise announcement that he would no longer be running for re-election amid the scrutiny and pressure. A former senior White House official who, like others in this article, was granted anonymity to speak candidly, said Trump has long been mystified by why then-Vice President Kamala Harris chose Walz as her running mate in 2024. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs never gotten Walz. Never gotten it,‚Äù the official said, saying Trump and his team believed someone like Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro would have been a stronger choice. For some in Minnesota, what made Good‚Äôs shooting especially tragic was that they saw something like it coming. Bringing in federal agents, against the wishes of the state‚Äôs political leaders ‚Äî and many of its residents ‚Äî was a bomb waiting to go off, Frey and Walz said Wednesday. ‚ÄúWhat we‚Äôre seeing is the consequences of governance designed to generate fear, headlines and conflict. It‚Äôs governing by reality TV, and today that recklessness cost someone their life,‚Äù Walz said in a news conference. ‚ÄúNow we hear more political rhetoric. Enough. Enough is enough.‚Äù Frey called the incident ‚Äútotally predictable‚Äù and ‚Äútotally avoidable‚Äù and told Immigration and Customs Enforcement to ‚Äúget the f--- out‚Äù of Minneapolis. On Fox News on Wednesday night, Vice President JD Vance declared that Walz should resign. He also made an admission. ‚ÄúLook, I‚Äôve beaten up on Tim Walz enough. I don‚Äôt want to do it anymore on your program,‚Äù Vance said. ‚ÄúI almost feel bad for the guy, except for the fact that he should have seen this,‚Äù he said, referring to the fraud allegations. On Thursday, however, Vance joined Leavitt at the press briefing, where he again went after Walz. ‚ÄúTim Walz is a joke,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúHis entire administration has been a joke, the idea that he‚Äôs some sort of freedom fighter. He‚Äôs not. He‚Äôs a guy who has enabled fraud, and maybe, in fact, has participated in fraud.‚Äù There is no evidence that Walz participated in alleged fraud. Leavitt also said the administration wouldn‚Äôt be taking its eye off Minnesota. ‚ÄúThe Department of Homeland Security will continue to operate on the ground in Minnesota, not only to remove criminal illegal aliens, but also to continue conducting door-to-door investigations of the rampant fraud that has taken place in the state under the failed and corrupt leadership of Democrat Gov. Tim Walz,‚Äù she announced. Tensions, years in the making Trump‚Äôs focus on Minnesota can be traced to 2016, when he first toppled the so-called blue wall and won Wisconsin, Michigan and Pennsylvania ‚Äî and saw Minnesota as potentially within reach. Republicans have not won Minnesota in a presidential election since 1972. In the view of one Democratic strategist who has worked in Minnesota, ‚Äúthe Trump folks thought if they squeezed Minnesota, they could turn it red.‚Äù Preya Samsundar, a Minnesota-based Republican strategist, noted Trump‚Äôs long-held goal of turning the state red and described the president‚Äôs attention and effort as a ‚Äúpoke in the eye‚Äù to Walz. ‚ÄúI think for a lot of folks, Minnesota is still one of those states that can be attainable with the right effort,‚Äù said Samsundar, a former Midwest regional communications director for the Republican National Committee. ‚ÄúI think now a part of the White House‚Äôs focus is because Tim Walz was a VP candidate from a state that Trump has wanted to flip for some while.‚Äù Until abandoning his campaign for a third term, Walz had been positioning himself as one of the Democratic Party‚Äôs future leaders, ‚Äúmaking him a convenient person to go after,‚Äù Samsundar added. Indeed, Trump‚Äôs criticism of Walz intensified after Harris chose him as her running mate. Trump frequently assailed Walz as a ‚Äúdangerously liberal extremist.‚Äù Walz, for his part, emerged as the Democratic ticket‚Äôs chief attack dog against Trump, further attracting his ire. After Trump won, he and his allies lumped Minnesota in with other Democratic states that, he said, weren‚Äôt aggressive enough on immigration. Minnesota is home to the nation‚Äôs largest Somali population, and most of them are U.S. citizens. Since 1993, thousands of people have fled war and instability in the East African country. As Trump has ramped up ICE actions across the U.S., the community, mostly based in the Twin Cities, has been the target of the agency‚Äôs efforts in Minnesota. And Walz hasn‚Äôt held his tongue regarding ICE, slamming it last year as Trump‚Äôs ‚Äúmodern-day Gestapo.‚Äù On Wednesday, Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker, a longtime Walz ally, called the governor to remind him to keep in mind what he was dealing with: a Trump administration that lies, according to a person with knowledge of the conversation. Pritzker also reupped a playbook he had shared in the past with Walz and other Democratic governors, which was to repeatedly remind his state‚Äôs residents that it was their right to protest the government but not to ‚Äútake the bait‚Äù and descend into violence. That was, Pritzker believed, exactly what the Trump administration wanted so it could declare martial law. Later Wednesday, Walz conveyed that to his residents, imploring them not to ‚Äútake the bait.‚Äù ‚ÄúThey want a show,‚Äù Walz said at his news conference. ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt give it to them.‚Äù Unfolding fraud allegations Meanwhile, a broad fraud scandal has been unfolding in the state involving the alleged misuse of hundreds of millions of dollars in federal welfare funds. The allegations pertain largely to the Somali community. Trump has repeatedly said the Somali community has ‚Äúdestroyed Minnesota‚Äú and ‚Äúour country,‚Äù and his Justice Department is sending additional federal prosecutors to the state to assist the U.S. attorney‚Äôs office there with the ongoing investigations into the matter. Republicans in the state and at the national level have blamed Walz for not taking the allegations seriously. ‚ÄúThe fraud is a powerful issue because it‚Äôs a real-life example of what the majority of Republicans and independents already feel is true ‚Äî that their tax dollars are wasted by politicians and people taking advantage of the system,‚Äù said Matt Wolking, a longtime GOP strategist who was on Trump‚Äôs 2020 campaign. A state Democratic lawmaker, however, said the Republican attacks all feel ‚Äúvery personal.‚Äù ‚ÄúDonald Trump has vendettas ‚Äî he goes after people. Clearly that‚Äôs a piece of this,‚Äù the person said. ‚ÄúThe city is emotionally fatigued,‚Äù added Roy Temple, a national Democratic operative with decades of experience in Minnesota politics, who said that, even six years later, the city is ‚Äústill healing‚Äù from the George Floyd murder and fallout. ‚ÄúPeople‚Äôs nerves are pretty shot,‚Äù Temple said, adding that the ICE raids and the fatal shooting are ‚Äútriggering.‚Äù Complicating part of the picture, however, is the scope and potential severity of the allegations of fraud. Other Democrats in the state agreed with the sentiment that Trump was unfairly attacking many elements of Walz‚Äôs record and dumping on the Somali community ‚Äî while also acknowledging the possibility that Walz hasn‚Äôt handled the situation well. ‚ÄúThis has been in the air in Minnesota for some time; it‚Äôs one of those things that we knew at some point this issue would really kind of percolate to the top. And we‚Äôre seeing that happen now, where a spotlight is put on this ‚Äî for multiple reasons,‚Äù a Minneapolis-based Democratic operative said. The operative added that Walz‚Äôs ‚Äúbiggest problem‚Äù with the fraud allegations was that ‚Äúhe just didn‚Äôt really have any good answers for any of this.‚Äù At a separate hearing in Congress this week on the Minnesota fraud issue, Democrats fumed about the hypocrisy of Trump administration officials who, while complaining about fraud and ICE protests in Democratic areas, pardoned fraudsters aligned with the president as well as those convicted of violence against federal officers on Jan. 6, 2021. Republicans in the state largely defended Trump‚Äôs message ‚Äî though not necessarily his tone ‚Äî expressing solidarity with efforts to unroot fraud and tackle immigration enforcement. ‚ÄúThe national attention that the president has brought to Minnesota means that people are listening now,‚Äù state GOP Chair Alex Plechash said.
news.summary: President Donald Trump and his allies have for weeks intensified scrutiny on Minnesota and its governor, Democrat Tim Walz.
news.author: Adam Edelman,Natasha Korecki

news.title: Jesse Ventura calls Trump 'coward,' says he's 'owed' another governor term
news.text:
In the wake of a deadly shooting by an immigration agent in his home state, former Minnesota Gov. Jesse Ventura slammed President Donald Trump and hinted at another run for office.

‚Äú(Trump is) the draft-dodging coward who, when it was his time to serve his country, he did what all rich white boys did. I wasn‚Äôt a rich white boy. We had to go," Ventura, 74, told local reporters Jan. 8 when asked for his response to the shooting of Renee Nicole Good by a federal immigration agent in Minneapolis. "He‚Äôs gonna tell me what courage is?"

Good's death, captured on video by witnesses, sparked protests and condemnation from local and state officials who refuted the Trump administration's assertion that the agent acted in self-defense.

Minneapolis shooting 'did not have to happen,' Ventura says

‚ÄúWhat occurred yesterday did not have to happen," Ventura told reporters, calling Good's shooting a "tragedy" and a "murder."

"We're a third-world country now," said Ventura, the WWE pro wrestling hall of famer who was Minnesota's governor from 1999 to 2003. "You wanna know why? I'm an expert. I've been there. I spent 17 months in Southeast Asia while the draft dodger was playing golf."

Ventura is a former Navy SEAL and Vietnam veteran. Trump was a member of the generation eligible to be drafted for the Vietnam War, but did not serve after receiving several student draft deferments and a medical exemption.

Some lawmakers have called for the arrest of the agent in the Minneapolis shooting, identified in court documents Jonathan Ross. A day after the shooting of Good, two people were injured on in a separate shooting involving federal agents in Portland, Oregon.

The shootings have highlighted growing tensions between the Trump administration's aggressive campaign to deport unauthorized immigrants and local leaders opposed to it.

‚ÄúFreedom is not arresting people without warrants," Ventura said. ‚ÄúWe have a system here. It‚Äôs called a Constitution, and we have a party, the Republicans, who don‚Äôt seem to want to abide by the Constitution.‚Äù

USA TODAY has reached out to the White House regarding Ventura's comments.

'Maybe it's time for Jesse' after Walz drops reelection bid

Ventura's comments come just days after Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz announced he would not run for a third term.

Walz, who was the Democratic nominee for vice president on Kamala Harris' 2024 campaign, dropped his reelection bid amid mounting pressure over allegations of fraud in the state's social services programs.

"Maybe it's time for Jesse. I only did one term. I'm owed a second," Ventura said.

Natalie Neysa Alund is a senior reporter for USA TODAY. Reach her at nalund@usatoday.com and follow her on X @nataliealund.
news.author: Usa Today

news.title: ‚ÄòGoing to start hitting land‚Äô: Donald Trump threatens military action against drug cartels in Mexico
news.text: Days after the United States carried out an operation in Venezuela, capturing the country‚Äôs president, Nicolas Maduro, who Washington accused of leading a drug cartel, President Donald Trump has warned of a similar military action in neighbouring Mexico. "We‚Äôve knocked out 97% of the drugs coming in by water, and we are going to start now hitting land with regard to the cartels," Trump told Fox News. BREAKING: Trump implies that he‚Äôs going to start bombing Mexico. ‚ÄúWe are gonna start hitting LAND with regard to the cartels. The cartels are running Mexico‚ÄùSomeone get me out of this nightmare. Imagine how much more peaceful a world this would be if Kamala Harris had won‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/ogh58RHJaT‚Äî Brian Krassenstein (@krassenstein) January 9, 2026 Since September 2025, the Trump administration has killed at least 115 people in more than 30 strikes on alleged drug-transporting boats in the Caribbean and the Pacific. Drug trafficking through US-Mexico border The US and Mexico share a border of around 3,145 kilometres, stretching from the Pacific Ocean to the Gulf of Mexico. Successive US governments have long accused their counterparts in Mexico of failing to crack down on the cartels smuggling drugs across the border. Shoppers and commuters walk through the Tacubaya open-air market in Mexico City, Wednesday, Jan. 7, 2026. (AP Photo/Marco Ugarte) Throughout his three presidential campaigns, Trump had made stopping the flow of illegal immigrants and drugs to the US from Mexico, one of his key promises. US sanctions Mexican cartels In February 2025, the US State Department had designated several major Mexican criminal organizations, including Sinaloa Cartel, C√°rtel de Jalisco Nueva Generaci√≥n, C√°rtel del Noreste, La Nueva Familia Michoacana, C√°rtel del Golfo and Carteles Unidos as Foreign Terrorist Organizations and Specially Designated Global Terrorists. also read After Venezuela, alarm bells in Mexico, Colombia, Cuba: What‚Äôs behind Trump‚Äôs latest threats? 'Cartels are running Mexico' On Thursday, Trump said Mexico was being run by the cartels. ‚ÄúThe cartels are running Mexico‚Äîit‚Äôs very, very sad to watch, and see what‚Äôs happened to that country,‚Äù he said. Mexican President responds Responding to Trump‚Äôs comments, Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum said that she has asked her foreign affairs secretary to reach out directly to Secretary of State Marco Rubio or the US President himself. FILE - Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum presents a new security strategy against violence for Michoacan state, at the National Palace, in Mexico City, Nov. 9, 2025. (AP Photo/Claudia Rosel, File) Sheinbaum also downplayed the remarks, saying ‚Äúit is part of his way of communicating.‚Äù She said she asked her Foreign Affairs Secretary, Juan Ram√≥n de la Fuente, to strengthen coordination with the US. Sheinbaum has repeatedly rebuffed Trump‚Äôs offer to send US troops after Mexican drug cartels. She has insisted that there will be no violation of Mexico‚Äôs sovereignty, but the two governments will continue to collaborate closely.
news.author: Express Web Desk

news.title: Mary Sheffield as Detroit's new mayor: 'Today we begin a new chapter'
news.text:
Mary Sheffield is the 76th mayor of Detroit. But, as she noted immediately after a public ceremonial swearing-in as Detroit's next leader, she is the first woman to helm a city founded in 1701.

From the city's poet laureate to the federal judge who offered the oath of office to Sheffield, the monumental nature of a Black woman becoming Detroit's mayor remained front and center.

"I am deeply grateful to be the first woman to lead this city in its 324-year history," Sheffield said while on stage Friday, Jan. 9, at the Detroit Opera House, thanking "courageous" women that came before her for their work that helped her achieve the office.

Sheffield, new Detroit City Council President James Tate and the city's other elected officials celebrated their new roles, waving to crowds of enthusiastic guests at the Opera House. Sheffield officially became mayor at the start of the new year.

She thanked her family and other city leaders for their help and support. She thanked former Mayor Mike Duggan for his work steering the city, words that garnered substantial applause and a standing ovation. And she thanked business leaders, noting they are aligned with city government.

But she spent the most time thanking Detroiters.

"To the people of Detroit, the soul and heartbeat of this city. Today, we begin a new chapter," she said.

"I embrace the responsibility of this historic moment. But this moment does not belong to one person: it belongs to every neighborhood in this city."

Sheffield said she had a long-standing belief in public service, instilled by the teachings and lives of her parents. She said in the city's next chapter, Sheffield and other leaders will draw on these historic teachings to guide them for the future.

"The question before us is clear: Where do we go from here Detroit? In this next chapter, we must commit ourselves to the work of building a beloved community, one that is rooted in dignity, justice and opportunity for every Detroiter," Sheffield said.

"In this administration, every voice will guide our path, including voices that far too often have been overlooked. We will work every single day to build a Detroit that works for everyone."

She pledged to make Detroit a city where families want to stay and where ambition is embraced.

"Let's rise higher together," she said, wrapping up her roughly 15-minute speech.

Tate, the new city council president and longtime member, said he was honored and grateful to take on the new leadership role. He noted Sheffield's growth as a member of the same city council, adding he feels exceptional to see "one of our own" ascend to the mayor's office.

"We will support Mayor Sheffield, and we will also push her when it is needed to ensure our residents are getting the results they deserve," Tate said shortly before Sheffield spoke.

"As we begin this new term, I am confident ... Detroit's best days are still ahead of us."

The group takes control of Michigan's largest city at a pivotal point: There's a $105 million surplus and more than $500 million in reserves, homicides hit their lowest levels in decades last year and expectations for ongoing growth remain high.

But obvious challenges are on the horizon. Many of Detroit's 200 neighborhoods want to share in the economic development growth enjoyed downtown. The potential for federal funding cuts remains present yet unpredictable. And there is the persistent problem of long-term population growth for a city that has watched hundreds of thousands of residents leave in recent decades.

In a scrum with reporters after the event, Sheffield reiterated that her administration will focus on improving the quality of life for all residents, whether that includes investments in neighborhoods, improving the educational system, building additional housing, driving down crime or increasing incomes for Detroiters.

‚ÄúWe hear that neighborhoods are oftentimes left out, have not been invested in. Sometimes, the individuals who may not have the resources to participate in government ‚Äî which in my entire time on council, I‚Äôve always prided myself on going to meet people where they are. So, we want to ensure that this is a government that listens to all, that we‚Äôre inclusive as possible,‚Äù Sheffield said.

Sheffield added that she will transition and expand her signature Occupy the Corner initiative ‚Äî an initiative to bring resources to neighborhoods ‚Äî that she started while on the city council, to Occupy the City to create safe spaces and empower Detroit‚Äôs youths.

‚ÄúYouth will be a central focus of this administration,‚Äù Sheffield said.

The investiture kicked off a few minutes after 10 a.m., honoring Sheffield, City Council members, the city clerk and board of police commissioners. The sold-out event ‚Äî holding a capacity of 2,700 ‚Äî serves as a historic moment for the city's top office, as voters elected the first-ever woman to lead Detroit.

Local musicians sang, welcoming attendees, while leaders from several faiths prayed for a prosperous, peaceful Detroit and successful tenure for Sheffield.

City Council members, the city clerk and members of the police board of commissioners raised their right hands and swore to faithfully fulfill their elected roles.

jessica Care moore, the city's poet laureate, offered an impassioned original piece celebrating Sheffield and her new space leading Detroit.

"The beauty is in the resume, legacy in her DNA," moore said of Sheffield, noting it took more than 300 years for the city to elect a woman to serve as mayor.

"She has actually been walking the actual walk, and when she runs, she actually runs. ... Mayor Sheffield knows exactly who she is, and so does the D."

Jennine Spencer-Gilbert, 55, president of the Field Street Block Club, showed up two weeks after having knee surgery to ring in the new mayor and elected officials and celebrate what she calls ‚Äúa very historic moment‚Äù for Detroit.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs the first Black woman to be mayor. It shows our young men and women what you can accomplish at any age. It's historic because it means so much to our communities, to our Black women, Black boys and girls, and all cultures. You can be anything that you want to be. I‚Äôm so proud and overwhelmed, and excited about this today. It‚Äôs a big win for, not just our city, but for our nation, and also our ancestors,‚Äù Spencer-Gilbert said. ‚ÄúThat allows us and other children of all races to know it doesn‚Äôt matter what race you are ‚Ä¶ you can win, you just have to believe and push hard.‚Äù

Spencer-Gilbert added that Sheffield has visited her neighborhood and others to help leverage grants for various quality of life issues, describing Sheffield as a ‚Äúreliable and dependable‚Äù leader.

Monique Smith, 54, attended to watch Sheffield be publicly sworn in, noting that her representation makes her ‚Äúfeel like nothing is out of reach.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you have a passion for something, keep fighting for it. Because she could‚Äôve easily just gave up and said, ‚ÄòI know they‚Äôre not gonna vote for a woman, look what Kamala (Harris) went through. They didn‚Äôt vote for her.‚Äô But she just kept going because she knew she had a vision for what she wanted Detroit to be,‚Äù Smith said.

Duggan and his wife attended the event, as did other prominent current or former elected leaders. That includes former U.S. Sen. Debbie Stabenow, state senator and current U.S. Senate candidate Mallory McMorrow, gubernatorial candidate and current Lt. Gov. Garlin Gilchrist and Macomb County Executive Mark Hackel.

Sheffield takes the top job after Duggan opted to run for governor instead of pursuing another term, 12 years after becoming mayor. Raised by a civil rights activist and an educator, Sheffield served 12 years on City Council, four as the council president.

She handily dispatched a bevy of challengers en route to the mayor's office. In the August primary she garnered 51% of the vote, 34 percentage points more than Triumph Church Pastor Solomon Kinloch Jr. In November, she cruised to a win, receiving roughly 77% of votes to 23% for Kinloch ‚Äî "that's not bad," Sheffield said, noting the percent of the vote she received. That's a larger margin of victory than any enjoyed by Duggan during his runs for mayor.

Detroit's officeholders officially began their roles on Jan. 1 and were required to legally take an oath of office per the city charter. Sheffield was surrounded by family and a few close colleagues during her official swearing-in with City Clerk Janice Winfrey.

Detroit's returning and new council members include: Tate, President Pro-Tem Coleman Young II, At-Large Councilmember Mary Waters, District 2 Member Angela Whitfield-Calloway, District 3 Member Scott Benson, District 4 Member Latisha Johnson, District 5 Member Renata Miller, District 6 Member Gabriela Santiago-Romero, District 7 Member Denzel McCampbell. Miller and McCampbell are the newest members on council.

City Council members on Monday, Jan. 5 appointed Tate and Young as leaders of the nine-member body.

Sheffield is hosting an inaugural ball at 7 p.m. at The Icon. The event is open to the public by purchasing tickets for $100 each. Proceeds will benefit the Homeless Action Network of Detroit, according to the invitation. The strolling event will feature small bites from Andiamo, live entertainment and brief remarks from the mayor.

Dana Afana is the Detroit City Hall reporter for the Free Press. Contact: dafana@freepress.com. Follow her: @DanaAfana
news.author: Detroit Free Press

news.title: Newsom Strains To Flip Script on California Failures
news.text:
It‚Äôs an odd predicament for a leading Democratic presidential contender. Gavin Newsom‚Äôs biggest strength ‚Äì political spin and performance come almost second nature to him ‚Äì could also be his biggest liability as he strains to remake the tarnished image of the state he has governed for the last seven years.

Newsom, with his smooth-talking, rapid-fire responses and his attempt to out-Trump Trump on social media aggression, is everything Kamala Harris wasn‚Äôt in 2024. But neither Californian can easily shake the biggest millstone dragging down their White House ambitions. Their failed progressive policies have sullied the Golden State‚Äôs image, driving up prices, homelessness, and mismanagement. The failures have not only driven citizens away but are also likely to turn off voters in swing battleground districts as well.

California‚Äôs failures weren‚Äôt Harris‚Äô biggest weakness in 2024 ‚Äì her word salads were. But the Golden State‚Äôs downward spiral was a close second.

As wildfire victims held vigils and prayer circles on the anniversary of the devastating Palisades and Eaton fires, Newsom on Thursday attempted to flip the script on California‚Äôs role as a GOP punchline.

In his final State-of-the-State address after years of releasing video-taped remarks, Newsom cast Trump‚Äôs control of Washington as a ‚Äúcarnival of chaos‚Äù amid the Democratic furor over an ICE agent shooting and killing a woman in Minnesota. He then positioned California as a ‚Äúbeacon‚Äù of fairness and resistance to Trump‚Äôs heavy-handed Washington rule.

Addressing the California legislature, which had just observed a moment of silence for the slain Minnesota woman, Renee Nicole Good, Newsom repeatedly pointed to Trump as a power-hungry threat to democracy who abused his power to call in the National Guard to quell unrest over ICE arrests and raids.

‚ÄúThe president believes that might makes right, that the courts are simply speed bumps, not stops. That democracy is a nuisance to be circumvented. Secret police, businesses being raided, windows smashed, citizens detained, citizens shot, masked men snatching, people in broad daylight, people disappearing,‚Äù Newsom charged.

‚ÄúNone of this is normal,‚Äù he added.

After throwing out the red meat for the Democratic base, Newsom then set out to normalize California‚Äôs dizzying array of failures under his watch.

‚ÄúThe state is providing a different narrative ‚Äî an operational model, a policy blueprint for others to follow,‚Äù he told state lawmakers.

Newsom‚Äôs defiant defense of his state as a shining example for others to emulate may come as a shock for those who haven‚Äôt been watching his reinvention as a social media agitator and leader of the national redistricting battle.

But Newsom‚Äôs attempt to go on offense on his biggest weakness ‚Äì his policy failures ‚Äì was his most audacious and sweeping thus far. After mimicking Trump‚Äôs belligerent social media style, Newsom stole another Trump play, labeling the state‚Äôs critics as suffering from ‚ÄúCalifornia Derangement syndrome,‚Äù a revision of the ‚ÄúTrump Derangement Syndrome,‚Äù which MAGA world deploys to brush off condemnation.

‚ÄúThe declinists,‚Äù the pundits and conservative critics simply don‚Äôt know the updated facts, Newsom asserted, arguing that they are working to ‚Äútear down, to try to attack all of our progress.‚Äù

Early data for 2025, he said, indicate a 9% decline in homelessness, the first drop after an explosion of unsheltered people in California. He failed to mention that from 2019 to 2024, under his watch, homelessness rose to 188,000, a net increase of 37,000, or 24%, even though the state spent roughly $24 billion trying to curb it.

‚ÄúSo, our investments paid off,‚Äù he claimed without an explanation.

Newsom acknowledged that the decline was ‚Äúnot good enough,‚Äù and more work needs to be done as long as big homeless encampments still exist in major cities around the state. He failed to mention the high number of homelessness deaths across the state that could be contributing to the 9% decline, as well as the danger of allowing any encampments to remain.

Just hours after the speech, a fire at a homeless camp in a Los Angeles suburb broke out, the second in the last two weeks.

Newsom also claimed credit for ‚Äúdouble-digit decreases in crime‚Äù across California, without acknowledging that those figures are still higher than pre-pandemic levels in some areas and that property crime continues to plague major cities such as San Francisco and Los Angeles.

While touting minor California successes, he often followed up by acknowledging that there is still ‚Äúwork to do‚Äù when it comes to bringing down housing costs, overall ‚Äúaffordability,‚Äù lowering crime rates, and improving fire insurance coverage.

Though he noted that he had debated whether or not to mention high-speed rail, another frequent target for fiscal conservative attacks, he hailed the $13.8 billion spent so far and progress on projects in the state‚Äôs agricultural Central Valley as one of the ‚Äúgreat economic investments‚Äù in the region. Those lines, he said, ‚Äúwill make commute times shorter and make life more affordable.‚Äù He failed to mention that the project was launched in 2008, and more than 17 years later, no trains are running.

Newsom even touted California‚Äôs status as having the highest taxes of any state in the country, stressing that Democrats in the state had designed the most ‚Äúprogressive‚Äù system in the country, which he argued is far fairer for middle-class and low-wage earners.

‚ÄúSo, the question to all of you ‚Äî who are the high tax states? Just consider Texas. Just consider Florida, the two most regressive tax states in America,‚Äù Newsom said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre hammering their low-income earners. They‚Äôre hammering them more than their wealthiest. Who are the high-tax states? California stands for fairness.‚Äù

California Republican Party Chairwoman Corrin Rankin, responding to the address, cast Newsom as not only out of touch but deranged.

‚ÄúGovernor Newsom told Californians that homelessness is down, crime is at record lows, schools are improving, and Los Angeles is recovering after the Palisades fires,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúGovernor Newsom painted a picture of a California that exists in his imagination.‚Äù

Rep. Kevin Kiley, a Republican representing parts of Sacramento in Congress, assailed the address as pure gaslighting.

‚ÄúFor once, Newsom is right,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúCalifornia has led the nation during his tenure ‚Äì in homelessness, unemployment, poverty, illiteracy, gas prices, electricity costs, debt, and outmigration. That is the true state of our state.‚Äù

Kiley also provided a preview of the conservative line of attack that could haunt the governor leading into the 2028 presidential race.

‚ÄúCalifornia, also, of course, leads the nation in fraud ‚Ä¶ Minnesota‚Äôs fraud scandals have just ended Tim Walz‚Äôs political career,‚Äù Kiley said. ‚ÄúCalifornia‚Äôs should likewise end Gavin Newsom‚Äôs.‚Äù

Susan Crabtree is RealClearPolitics' national political correspondent.
news.summary: It's an odd predicament for a leading Democratic presidential contender. Gavin Newsom's biggest strength - political spin and performance come almost second nature to him - could also be his biggest liability as he strains to remake the tarnished image of the state he has governed for the last seven years.
news.author: RealClearPolitics,Susan Crabtree

news.title: Must-read Indian books of 2026: 23 most-anticipated titles to get your hands on this year
news.text:
It‚Äôs fair to say that the Indian books of 2026 have their work cut out for them with 2025 being a mammoth publishing year that gave us bestselling, award-winning titles like Arundhati Roy‚Äôs Mother Mary Comes to Me, Kiran Desai‚Äôs The Loneliness of Sonia and Sunny and Banu Mushtaq‚Äôs Heart Lamp. But with memoirs and tell-alls by fashion designer Prabal Gurung, film journalist Khalid Mohammed and Bollywood actor Shefali Shah as well as Shalini Passi‚Äôs guidebook to being fabulous for women, our TBR pile may just get some juicy additions after all. There are heavy-hitters too: International Booker Prize winner Geetanjali Shree and Booker nominee Avni Doshi return with new works and sequels like Intergalactic Feast: Flavour Hacker and Red Alert come to bookstores this year. As always, it‚Äôs been a task to compile since there are so many worthy contenders but here is our list of the most-anticipated Indian books of 2026 that we can‚Äôt wait to get our hands on.
Once Elephants Lived Here by Geetanjali Shree
International Booker‚Äìwinning author Geetanjali Shree is back with a collection of short stories that offers a glimpse into her inner thoughts while writing the acclaimed Tomb of Sand. The winner of the 2025 PEN Translates Award, the collection promises to transcend readers‚Äô expectations of the short-story genre. It explores themes of change, resilience and loss and has been translated from Hindi to English by translator Daisy Rockwell, who also translated Shree‚Äôs International Booker‚Äìwinning novel, Tomb of Sand.
The Ghosts of Indian Small Towns: A Journey Through Time by Ruskin Bond (Aleph Book Company)
From one of the biggest chroniclers of small-town life comes a new book that discusses how India once had an answer to the question of what lies between cities and villages. But with small towns now disappearing as people move to the city in search of better lives, what becomes of a heart that is pulled in both directions? Ruskin Bond writes about what it means for us to have these beautiful, individual pockets of tranquillity, which we are now rapidly losing to pollution and urbanisation.
Make It Up as You Go Along: A Sort-of Memoir by Shefali Shah (Bloomsbury India)
Emmy-winning actress Shefali Shah writes a tell-all about 30 years of experience in the film industry. One of India‚Äôs most well-known and respected actresses, Shah breaks down the ageism and sexism in the glitzy and glamorous world of Bollywood. She also discusses the changing landscape of film and television, the streaming wars and the OTT revolution.
Fieldwork as a Sex Object by Meena Kandasamy (HarperCollins India)
Meena Kandasamy‚Äôs protagonist in her new book is a young Indian woman living in London who faces brutal online trolling because of a sex scandal. Through her trademark razor-sharp writing, the Exquisite Cadavers author presents a nuanced narrative about race, politics, sex and sexuality, resulting in a novel that will simultaneously shock and reel in readers.
The First House by Avni Doshi (Penguin Random House India)
After her debut novel Girl in White Cotton (now Burnt Sugar) was published in 2019 and shortlisted for the Booker Prize the following year, Avni Doshi spent the next five years writing The First House. A deeply layered book, its title hints at an astrological reference, with Doshi describing it as being about ‚Äúdissolving and coming back together, the cost of refusing to see what is in front of us, and how the cosmos mirrors the rhythms of our lives‚Äîif only we would look.‚Äù
Aamchi Mumbai: My City in Stories and Poems by Gulzar (HarperCollins India)
Having lived in Mumbai for seven decades, there is no one other than Gulzar who can write a book like this one. A treat for all Mumbai residents and Gulzar fans alike, this bilingual collection of stories and poems is a love letter to the busy city.
Begum Samru Biography by Ira Mukhoty (Penguin Random House India)
Ira Mukhoty‚Äôs new biography chronicles the extraordinary life of Begum Samru, once a tawaif who became a ruler and patron in an era when women were famously subservient. The critically acclaimed writer of narrative history highlights the role women like Begum Samru played in shaping the future of India and how they defied expectations and conventions to achieve greatness.
Intergalactic Feast: Flavour Hacker, Book 2 by Lavanya Lakshminarayan (HarperCollins India)
Sequel to the critically acclaimed novel, award-winning sci-fi writer Lavanya Lakshminarayan‚Äôs Interstellar MegaChef, Intergalactic Feast: Flavour Hacker picks up three months after Saraswati Kaveri and Serenity Ko win Interstellar MegaChef with their groundbreaking new food simulation, Feast. The duo must fight the forces that threaten to undo everything they have accomplished as they figure out their complicated feelings for each other.
Red Alert by Sunil Gupta and Samanwaya Rautray (Penguin Random House India)
Former superintendent of Tihar Jail and co-writer of Black Warrant, Sunil Gupta returns with another book about his time at India‚Äôs biggest prison. Co-written with journalist Samanwaya Rautray, the book picks up where Gupta left us in the previous one, chronicling the jailer‚Äôs experiences in the prison, including a series of jailbreaks‚Äîthe biggest in all of Asia. We also meet prisoners like the psychopathic Charles Sobhraj and Sher Singh Rana, the killer of dacoit-turned-parliamentarian Phoolan Devi.
The Art of Being Fabulous by Shalini Passi (Penguin Random House India)
Known for being an art collector with great taste and a reality TV show contestant with unrivalled aura, Fabulous Lives vs Bollywood Wives‚Äôs Shalini Passi writes a part-memoir, part-manifesto about what ‚Äòfabulous‚Äô means to her. In it, Passi lists ten key paths to a fabulous life and defines fabulousness in her own way‚Äîa form of profound self-trust and the courage to carry one‚Äôs own story rather than seeking external validation.
Walk Like a Girl: A Memoir by Prabal Gurung (HarperCollins India)
Walk Like a Girl tells the story of Prabal Gurung, a queer boy who moved to America dreaming of a freer world after a rough childhood in India and Nepal. Gurung shares his experiences of facing discrimination even in the States and breaks down his subsequent rise within the fashion industry, having dressed the likes of Oprah Winfrey, Michelle Obama and Kamala Harris. The book is also an ode to his mother, Durga Rana, who always supported him and encouraged him to be his best self.
Ticket to Kerala: The Story of Malayalam Cinema by S. R. Praveen (Rupa Publications India)
As present-day Malayalam cinema continues to break records, Ticket to Kerala traces the industry‚Äôs journey all the way back to its beginnings. The book reveals unknown early stories‚Äîhow the first director in Malayalam cinema never made another film and how the first actress was forced to flee after fear of casteist attacks. Serving as an accessible introduction to Malayalam cinema beyond just its recent successes, Ticket to Kerala brings to light the tragic origins behind the record-breaking industry we know and love today.
Absolute Jafar by Sarnath Banerjee (HarperCollins India)
Graphic novelist Sarnath Banerjee writes about home in his latest release, Absolute Jafar. Born to Indo-Pak parents, Jafar grows up in Berlin, hearing stories of jinns, eccentric cousins and Karachi, Delhi and Calcutta from his father. Facing a world where bureaucracies and borders shape our lives and relationships, the novel promises to be a sweet meditation on belonging and becoming.
Biting Off More Than I Can Chew by Rahul Akerkar (HarperCollins India)
From one of India‚Äôs first culinary rebels, Biting Off More Than I Can Chew is a memoir that captures visionary chef Rahul Akerkar‚Äôs journey from cooking in his mum‚Äôs kitchen to launching Indigo, a world-famous restaurant, in 1999, and later walking away from it.
The Girls Club by Harnidh Kaur (Penguin Random House India)
The Girls Club is a book written for women who have at some point in life asked, exasperatedly, ‚ÄúWhy didn‚Äôt anyone teach us this?‚Äù Kaur describes the book as ‚Äúa quiet space for everything I‚Äôve learned as a woman, a sister, a daughter, a professional, a funder and a bit of a menace. The lessons I wish I had. The things no one told me. The truths that stuck, and the ones I‚Äôm still learning to hold.‚Äù As tender as it is fierce, the book is a survival guide for the modern young Indian woman trying to make it in the corporate workplace.
Mammals of India by A.J.T. Johnsingh and P.O. Nameer (HarperCollins India)
The first comprehensive guide to mammals in India that lists around 450 mammals found in different regions of the country, Mammals of India has been written in collaboration with the Bombay Natural History Society (BNHS). It also includes 400 distribution maps and 50 pages of illustrations‚Äîappealing to experts and general readers alike.
Not Quite Family: An Intimate Memoir of Bollywood by Khalid Mohammed (HarperCollins India)
Film journalist Khalid Mohammed writes a tell-all about his years in the film industry. The book features endearing portraits of Bollywood stars like Smita Patil, Shah Rukh Khan, Dharmendra, Rekha and others.
The Sharma Sisters by Rachel Fernandes (Penguin Random House India)
A contemporary British Indian reimagining of Little Women, The Sharma Sisters features Kav, Mally, Trina and Ori‚Äîfour sisters with very different personalities and lifestyles. The book explores themes of family, friendship and ambition, wrapped in a coming-of-age story.
Your Perfect Dream Girl by Sukhnidh Kaur (Penguin Random House India)
27-year-old Sukhnidh Kaur identifies as a doer of a little bit of everything, having transitioned from studying and working in the humanities to working with tech companies like Apple, Microsoft and TikTok. Her debut novel discusses how desire, algorithms and technology have shaped her girlhood and how they affect the world at large.
The Simp by Roshan Sethi (Hachette India)
Raj Ladlani is a queer Indian man living in America who dreams of being a big Hollywood star during his shifts at Yogurtland. Things take a nightmarish turn, however, when he accepts a job doing menial tasks for a Hollywood power couple‚ÄîJim, a macho director determined to prove himself as an artist, and Anna, his much younger wife, who has ambitions of her own.
I Wept at My Own Grave: A Memoir by Dr Aqsa Shaikh (Bloomsbury India)
A memoir by India‚Äôs first openly transgender doctor, this book is written by Dr Aqsa for parents, teachers and anyone seeking to understand the trans experience. Though her story is far from over, she shares the many joys, shocks and confusions that come with being a trans person, hoping her journey might help someone in their time of need. The result is an honest, vulnerable account of living as a transgender medical professional in India.
Hometown: A Personal History of Shillong by Anjum Hasan (Bloomsbury India)
A lively biography of one of the most interesting places in India, Anjum Hasan zooms in on the centre of Meghalaya: the culturally layered city of Shillong. Through the voices of its residents, Hasan discusses the music scene, culture, politics and violence as well as the dreams and aspirations of the people who live there.
Appropriation by Tanuj Solanki (Simon & Schuster India)
A writer is murdered, and a detective must crack the case; Josef Konrad, a sailor, arrives in Calcutta during the British reign in India; a couple‚Äôs relationship breaks down while there‚Äôs a lizard in their room. Tanuj Solanki‚Äôs collection of short stories features a dreamlike world sprinkled with harsh glimpses of reality that showcase his range as a writer.
This list will be updated.

Banu Mushtaq on her life post-Booker and how she‚Äôs coping with having no time to write
Anuradha Roy‚Äôs new book is your sign to move to the mountains to be a better writer
In defence of buying books you may never read
news.summary: With new books by Gulzar, Ruskin Bond, Geetanjali Shree and Avni Doshi all releasing this year, our to-be-read pile is already looking good
news.author: Asma Siddiqui

news.title: ICE shooting live updates: New video emerges, Renee Good's wife speaks out
news.text:
Tensions remained high on Friday as two separate shootings involving immigration agents in Minneapolis and Portland, Oregon, drew protesters to the streets and deepened fractures between federal and state officials.

Vice President JD Vance shared footage on social media that appeared to show a new perspective on the fatal ICE shooting of Renee Nicole Good in Minneapolis, saying the officer acted in self defense, while criticizing "media dishonesty" over the incident.

Video analysis shows how fatal ICE shooting in Minneapolis unfolded

Prosecutors in Minneapolis announced efforts to independently investigate the death of Good, a 37-year-old mother of three, and asked for the public's help in acquiring evidence. The move comes after Minnesota state investigators said the FBI blocked local authorities from case materials.

"We in Minneapolis want a fair investigation,‚Äù Mayor Jacob Frey said at a news conference. ‚ÄúIf you have nothing to hide, then don't hide from it."

More: Video analysis shows how fatal ICE shooting in Minneapolis unfolded

Good's wife, Rebecca Good, released a statement describing her partner as a dedicated Christian who had "stopped to support our neighbors" before she was fatally shot. "We had whistles. They had guns," Rebecca Good said. The agent involved has been identified as Jonathan Ross, a U.S. Army veteran and former Border Patrol agent, newly released documents show.

President Donald Trump and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem have said Renee Good struck an ICE agent with her car before she was shot. State officials dispute those claims.

In Portland, tensions flared after a Border Patrol officer shot and wounded two people on Thursday. Federal officials described the victims as undocumented immigrants with ties to the Venezuelan gang Tren de Aragua. Local prosecutors said they launched an investigation and the mayor demanded that federal agents leave Portland.

More: Agents have killed 4 people since Trump boosted migrant enforcement

More: ICE officer in shooting was Iraq vet, ex-Border Patrol

How many weekend ICE protests?

More than 1,000 anti-ICE protests are scheduled nationwide for Saturday, Jan. 10 and Sunday, Jan. 11 following the shooting death of Renee Nicole Good in Minneapolis.

"There's widespread anger right now. It's organic," said Ezra Levin, cofounder of the progressive group Indivisible, which helps organize rallies and train local activists.

‚àíSarah D. Wire

More: Where are ICE protests taking place this weekend? Here's what to know

Trump defends FBI's Minneapolis freeze-out, citing election claims
